sols_html:
When \(y = x^{r}\), we know that \(y' = rx^{r-1}\) and \(y'' = r(r-1)x^{r-2}\). Hence, we have

\[\begin{aligned} 0 &= x^2 y'' + 4xy' + 2y \\ &= x^2 (r(r-1)x^{r-2} ) + 4x(rx^{r-1}) + 2x^{r} \\ &= (r^{2}-r)x^{r} + 4rx^{r} + 2x^{r} \\ &= (r^{2}+3r+2)x^{r}\end{aligned}\]

Now, since \(x > 0\) always, we must have that the coefficient of \(x^{r}\) above has to be 0. Thus, we solve

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 0 = r^{2}+3r+2 = (r+1)(r+2)\end{aligned}\]

and so \(r = -1\) and \(r = -2\) completing the question.

statement_html:
For what values of \(r\) does the function \(y = x^r\) satisfy the following differential equation (for \(x > 0\))?

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x^2 y'' + 4xy' + 2y = 0\end{aligned}\]
